Evidence Act, 1872 - Ss. 45 and 9 - Presence of fingerprints scene of crime - Evidentiary value in absence of non-holding of TIP - Appellants found to be unknown faces to sole child eyewitness, and not subjected to any a test identification - Apart from identification by the child witness in court for the first time, there was no other material to establish their presence on the spot - Held, even if fingerprints lifted from the house of the deceased could be associated with the appellants, that by itself, in the absence of any substantive piece of evidence, cannot be made the basis of their conviction - Appellants, therefore acquitted by giving benefit of doubt - Penal Code, 1860, S. 396 b H. Criminal Trial - Circumstantial Evidence - Conviction on basis of - Principles reiterated The issues that arose before the Supreme Court were: (i) Whether the testimony of sole child eyewitness (PW 5) was completely worthy of reliance and going by the rule of prudence, the version given by him was fully corroborated on material particulars so as to be sufficient to base conviction of the appellant thereon? (ii) Whether in prosecution under Section 396 IPC, liability of accused persons could be fastened with the help of only fingerprint expert's report? Allowing the appeal, the Supreme Court Held: Issue (i): Testimony of sole child eyewitness The evidence of the child witness cannot be rejected per se, but the court, as C d a rule of prudence, is required to consider such evidence with close scrutiny and only on being convinced about the quality of the statements and its reliability, base e conviction by accepting the statement of the child witness. If the child witness is shown to have stood the test of cross-examination and there is no infirmity in her evidence, the prosecution can rightly claim a conviction based upon her testimony alone. Corroboration of the testimony of a child witness is not a rule but a measure of caution and prudence. Some discrepancies in the statement of a child witness cannot be made the basis for discarding the testimony. Discrepancies in f the deposition, if not in material particulars, would lend credence to the testimony of a child witness who, under the normal circumstances, would like to mix up what the witness saw with what he or she is likely to imagine to have seen. While appreciating the evidence of the child witness, the courts are required to rule out the possibility of the child being tutored. In the absence of any allegation regarding tutoring or using the child witn e ss for ulterior purposes of the prosecution, the g courts have no option but to rely upon the confidence inspiring testimony of such witness for the purposes of holding the accused guilty or not. The evidence of the child witness must be evaluated more carefully and with greater circumspection because a child is susceptible to be swayed by what others tell him and thus an easy prey to tutoring. The evidence of the child witness must find adequate corroboration before it is relied upon, as the rule of corroboration is of practical wisdom than of h law. The mobile of his mother definitely received a call at about 9.27 p.m. from another mobile. The call lasted for 20 seconds. However, there is nothing on record that the mobile concerned was that of accused H, or any of the accused. The record does not throw any light, nor were any efforts made by the investigating machinery to trace the name of the person holding this mobile phone number. However, there is some corroboration available from the testimony of PW 2 OS that on 28-10-2008 he had found H standing near a vehicle in the vicinity of the house of the deceased; and upon being asked, accused H had replied that he was calling N (deceased). However, according to PW 2 OS, that was at about 11.00 p.m. and not at or about 9.27 p.m. (Para 23.1.1) After being admitted into the house, tea and water was offered to accused H and his associates. There were glasses which were found in the kitchen which fact certainly corroborates the version given by PW 5 U. (Para 23.1.2) It was stated that his mother was overpowered by two of the accomplices and her throat was slit by accused H. Thereafter, his three siblings were throttled to death, and an attempt was also made to throttle PW 5 U. The manner in which his mother and siblings were done to death is corroborated by the medical evidence on record. However, if the mother was being overpowered, there were no signs of struggle and none of her bangles was broken. Further, if her throat was slit and her left side blood vessels of the neck and trachea were cut, the blood would have instantaneously gushed out. But, there were no blood spots anywhere else except below the cot where the body of N was found lying in supine condition. One more striking feature of the matter is that there was no medical evidence either in the form of any documents, pictures or even a statement of any medical professional that PW 5 U was given medical attention as a result of attempts of throttling. (Para 23.1.3) The location of dead bodies, as mentioned by him, is undoubtedly corroborated by the site map, inquest panchnama and other material. (Para 23.1.4) Having dealt with the features which get corroborated to some extent, there are certain inconsistencies or infirmities which are evident from the record. Moreover, the other person, namely, Dr SS to whom similar narration was given by PW 5 U, was not even examined by the prosecution. (Para 25.5) The charge-sheet did indicate Dr SS to be one of the relevant witnesses, and yet he was not examined. On the other hand, the charge-sheet did not even speak of PW 5 U to be a relevant and material witness. Insofar as accused SY and SH are concerned, apart from the material that their sample fingerprints matched with those lifted from the house of the deceased, nothing was brought on record to suggest or suspect the involvement of said two accused. They were acquitted of the charges under Section 412 IPC and under the Arms Act. Whether their liability in the instant case can be fastened with the help of the fingerprint expert's report is the question. (Para 31) According to the record, Ext. Ka- 7 was the panchnama testifying the lifting of the fingerprints from the house of the deceased by constable DS. If the fingerprints were picked from the glasses there is nothing to indicate what method was applied to lift the fingerprints from the glasses allegedly used by the accused when they were offered water. What the record indicates is that some photographs were sent to the office of the Director, Fingerprint Bureau and nothing more. It does not show the procedure adopted for taking such photographs, and whether such method is a trusted and tested one. The person concerned was not examined, who could have thrown light on these issues. The record also does not show whether those glasses by themselves were made available for appropriate analysis. There is, thus, no clarity in the process adopted by the investigating machinery. (Para 32) The procedure detailed in the Kamataka Police Manual captures the importance of development and preservation as well as the method of packing and safe keeping. Such a procedure, if adopted, will not raise any doubts. Conduct of the investigating officer in keeping the material concerned with him for almost two months, was not approved by the Supreme Court. In the present case, Constable DS was not examined by the prosecution. There is nothing on record regarding the competence of said DS, and whether he was adequately trained, or was an expert in lifting the fingerprints from material such as glasses; nor was any evidence led detailing out the procedure adopted by him. In the absence of any such material, it is extremely difficult to rely on the report that the lifted fingerprints from the glasses matched with the sample fingerprints of accused SY and SH. (Para 34) In any case, apart from the fingerprints, there was nothing else on record against these two accused. One thing is clear that evidence of fingerprint expert is not substantive evidence. Such evidence can only be used to corroborate some items of substantive evidence which are otherwise on record. Apart from identification by PW 5 U in Court for the first time, there is no other material to establish their presence. LALIT, J.- In Sessions Trial No. 234 of 2008, six accused persons, namely, Sanjay alias Sonu, Rijwan, Haseen Khan, Hari Orn alias Hero, Saurabh alias Sanju, Rafique alias Bhaiye alias Fareed were tried for having committed offences punishable under Sections 396, 412 of the Penal Code, 1860 ("IPC") and under Section 3(2)(v) of the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes (Prevention of Atrocities) Act, 1989 ("the SC/ST Act"). These six accused were also tried by the Additional Sessions Judge-2, Firozabad ("the trial court") for offences under Section 25 of the Arms Act, 1959 in Sessions Trial Nos. 235, 239, 237, 238 and 236 of 2008 and 504 of 2011, respectively. By its common judgment in said seven trials, the trial court recorded as under: "Convict Hariom alias Hero is awarded death sentence for the offence under Section 396 IPC. He shall be hanged till death. This order related to death sentence shall be in accordance with the confirmation of the Hon'ble High Court under Section 366 CrPC. Accused Hariom alias Hero is acquitted from Section 412 IPC and Section 3(2)(v) of the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes (Prevention of Atrocities) Act and from Section 25, Arms Act in Crime No. 371 of 2008.
